section-block.rac_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Big Book: Baby Animals with Their Families

section-block.rac_book_summary: This informational text describes animal families of all types, and tells how animals take care of their babies. Get ready to count and describe all these baby animals and their families!

section-block.rac_body-text: Call out numbers from 1 to 10 and ask children to hold up their fingers to show each number. For numbers 2 to 9, discuss different combinations of fingers on each hand.
Choose a familiar animal song like “Five Little Speckled Frogs” to get children excited about counting the members of animal families.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Baby Animals with Their Families by Suzi Eszterhas.
Lala loves all sorts of books. She really likes looking for numbers in informational texts like this one!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read: What is one way animal parents care for their babies?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Counting: While reading, provide opportunities for children to count different animals.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see the words care and support. We’re going to read about how animals care for and support their babies.
Albatross families include one mom, one dad, and one chick. How many birds are in an albatross family?
Are there still three birds if I count in a different order?
When I read, I like to ask how questions. How is this polar bear mom caring for her cubs? (MB)
Sloth moms give their babies a lot of support.
section.rac_body-text: Point to the small picture on page 14.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How many sloths do you see? Are there still two sloths if I count in this order instead?
This page names lots of relatives for a baby elephant. Let’s count the elephant relatives on our fingers as I say each one. How many is that in all?
Let’s talk about the guiding question: What is one way animal parents care for their babies?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Animal parents keep their babies warm.
Animal parents play with their babies.
Animal parents help their babies find food.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short number sentences about animal families as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How could an animal parent help their baby when it’s cold?
Animal parents keep their babies w_____ (warm).
Animal parents keep their babies warm.
How does your family care for you?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Remind children that they can count anything, any time! Help children hone their counting skills by incorporating counting into activities and situations throughout the day. Whenever you use a group of items, ask a volunteer to count the number of objects and tell the class how many there are in all.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Ask and Answer Questions

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: You ask questions to learn something new, and you answer questions to share what you know. Sometimes even when we know one answer, we can still have more questions! Reading an informational text is a great time to ask many questions about who, what, where, when, why, and how!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit Baby Animals with Their Families and ask and answer questions about the animals we see.
When Clifford reads, he likes to ask lots of questions to find out new things!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the book to see how we can use our ask and answer questions Mind Builder.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to ask and answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This lion dad and cub are playing. Let’s ask a how question: How do lions play together?
What other how question could you ask about these lions? (MB)
A group of topi is called a herd. How many topi are in this herd? Can you count only the adult topi? Let’s count using our fingers.
Sloths have small families, just one mother and one baby. How many sloths in all? Let’s count one at a time.
Who can think of a why question about sloth families? (MB)
These elephants are saying hello using their trunks. That’s like having a conversation. What do you think an elephant conversation would be like?
Point to the small picture.
I see lots of cheetah eyes. Let’s count them using our fingers.
What if we count them in this order instead? How many eyes are there in all now?
Can you show this number using only one hand? Why or why not?

section.rac_body-text: Place children in groups of five. Ask each group to pretend to be an animal family. Encourage children to talk to each other as animal family members, asking and answering questions to create an animal conversation.
Transcribe children’s speech as they count and discuss baby animals.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Asking questions is a key way children learn. Encourage them to ask questions for both of these reasons: to learn something they don’t yet know (“What is the biggest animal in the world?”), and to learn more about something they already know a little about (“If whales are so big, how do they get enough food?”). (“Prekindergarten Guidelines,” 2015)

section-block.rac_body-text: Introduce addition. Hold up three fingers on your left hand. Then, hold up two fingers on your right hand. Count all of the fingers across both hands to show the total count.
Have five children stand in a circle and ask how many children there are. Ask two children to step aside and ask how many are left. Repeat with other combinations of five.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Baby Animals with Their Families by Suzi Eszterhas.
Lala loves reading Baby Animals with Their Families because there are so many animals to count!
As we read today, I want you to think about this question: How do animals keep their babies safe?

section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s answer a what question to show what we’ve learned. What is a baby albatross called? (MB)
How many baby topis do you see? Let’s count on one hand.
How many adult topis do you see? Let’s count on the other hand.
Are those numbers the same? How can you tell?
pages 10–11
Let’s ask a where question to find out more. Where do these cubs go to stay safe from the cold? (MB)
How many cubs do you see in this picture? How many adult bears do you see? Let’s add those two numbers together. How many bears are there in all?
How many baby whales do you see in this picture? Let’s count on one hand.
How many adult whales are keeping the baby safe? Let’s count on the other hand.
Which number is fewer: the number of adults or babies?
Let’s answer a how question to show what we’ve learned. How does a mother sloth keep her baby safe? (MB)
How many sloths are in the small picture? How many sloths are in the large picture? Are these numbers the same?
Did you listen and remember as we read today? How do animals keep their babies safe?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses.
Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about how animals keep their babies safe.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why do whales swim near their babies?
Whales swim near their babies to pr___ (protect) them.
Whales swim near their babies to protect them.
What are some ways you keep safe every day?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Subtraction poses a unique challenge because some children may struggle with the concept of being left with a lesser number or amount than they started with. You can help them internalize this concept by always phrasing a subtraction question the same way: “How many do you have left?” or “What are you left with?”

section-block.rac_body-text: Revisit and discuss the ways animals care for and support their babies, asking children if they remember one way animals keep their babies safe.
Invite children to sit in a circle and play a game of “Duck, Duck, Goose,” substituting the word “chick” for “duck” and “hen” for “goose.”

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Chicks Say, “Pio, Pio, Pio.” It is an informational poster about a mother hen and her chicks.
Baby Animals with Their Families and The Chicks Say, “Pio, Pio, Pio” both focus on animal families. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Baby Animals with Their Families.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about this week’s question:
How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask these questions. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s ask a why question to find out more. Why do you think the chicks are crying? (MB)
Let’s count the number of chicks we see on one hand.
Let’s count the number of flowers we see on the other hand.
Which number is less? Are there fewer chicks or fewer flowers?
Let’s ask a how question to find out more. How does the mother hen offer her chicks shelter? (MB)
Which animals in Baby Animals with Their Families give shelter?
Let’s count the number of chicks in each picture using our fingers. Are there the same number of chicks each time? How can you tell?

section.rac_body-text: Play a pattern game. Have children sit in a circle. Start with the ABAB pattern: food, pio, food, pio. Continue once around the circle, with each child saying the next word in the pattern. Then, extend the pattern to ABBABB: food, pio, pio, food, pio, pio.
Provide a writing prompt about counting animal babies and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Help children recognize patterns in math by showing them that there are patterns all around them. Color and shape patterns are often visible on clothing. Environmental patterns are present in rows of houses and windows in a building. Even your classroom has patterns everywhere! Challenge children to identify patterns they see in the room.

section-block.rac_body-text: Being able to describe animals is an important science goal. Name each animal in the book, and invite children to reply with a word or phrase that describes it.
Have children stand in a circle as a “herd.” Have two children come to the middle for shelter. Ask three children to join them, and ask how many have shelter now. Repeat.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Baby Animals with Their Families one last time this week.
Who remembers whether this book tells us a story or teaches us information?
We learned many ways animals help their babies live, learn, and grow. As we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one way people help their babies live, learn, and grow?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s ask a what question to find out more. What do you think father lions look out for? (MB)
Let’s pretend to be lions looking out for our cubs!
Let’s answer a how question to show what we know. How do albatrosses find their chicks? (MB)
Who can make a special albatross call? How do you and your family make sure you stay together?
I see the word predators. Topi travel in herds to protect their babies. How does your family help keep you safe from danger?
Let’s make a whale family! I need two whales to swim together, one baby and one mom.
Now, who can be grandma and grandpa? When grandma and grandpa join mom and baby, how many whales are swimming in all?
Who can point to and count all of the bat-eared foxes in this picture? If mom leaves to hunt, how many foxes are left in the den? Show me using your fingers.
Let’s talk about the guiding question. What is one way people help their babies live, learn, and grow?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses.
Invite children to draw or write a number story about animal families and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do people help their babies grow?
People feed their babies healthy f___ (food).
People feed their babies healthy food.
Do you think it’s easy or hard to help a baby learn, live, and grow? Why?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Use visual aids to help children strengthen their ability to recognize numbers. Show children the corresponding number cards as you say each number aloud.
